comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The pier has been extended since the photo, and the steps shown here replaced. The 1902 map (OS-8-1-1-2 at the OSNI historical site) shows the pier as in the photo, the photographer would have been right at the tip. The Pier is not changed on the 1920 map, so no help in dating this one... .

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Ardglass grew from a place of little note in the 13th century to a modestly prosperous port in the 15th century.It was an important town and port in the Middle Ages, but no harbour works seem to have been constructed until after 1812. Then William Ogilvie, who had acquired the Ardglass estate, had a harbour built. Further extensions to the pier and a lighthouse were made, but in 1838 a great storm undermined the lighthouse which fell into the sea along with the end of the pier. Work on the piers was completed by 1885 and they remain in use to this day.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Online Exhibition UCD www.ucd.ie/archives/html/exhibit2.htm The Fishing Industry, Ardglass, Co. Down 'Ardglass, Co. Down. 1911. Fishing Industry. Local sailing fleet being displaced by English steam drifters which land and sell their catch, and get back to the fishing banks before the sailing boats reach the market. As a result of our visit some of the fishermen have obtained loans from the Department to equip their boats with motors. It is interesting that we see both Steam and sail in this photo.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
30622421@N03
comment._content: Oh what a great image!! I know I am not much good at ferretting out info but I will add this wee memory - I used to spend all my childhood holidays near here and remember in the late 1950s and early 1960s the "herring girls" still packing fish in those barrels in salt. They were gutted at tables and then packed. It was fascinating to watch and the gulls were ever present!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Part of a transcript from BBC Radio. www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/work/northern_ireland/ni_10/audio_... The herring were cleaned out and put into barrels with salt, mainly by a migrant labour-force of Scottish women. They were employed by the processing companies at Ardglass and would arrive from Scotland from April to September. ...early morning on the quay presented an indesrcibable scene. Overhead the screaming of the gulls, down below the creak of the winches as the crates of fish were hauled up from the little ships, tied up, two or three abreast.There was the cries of the buyers and most picturesque the fishergirls from Petershead in their gay shawls and petticoats, the ready laugh on their lips, the shrill word on their tongue as they leaned over the troughs, gutting the silvery mass with sure and swift stroke of the knife...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Despite the fame as a port, Ardglass never produced a community of fishermen. Even at the turn of the century when hundreds of boats from Portavogie, Kilkeel, the Isle of Man and the Scottish ports, there were never more than half a dozen local boats..........

That explains the lack of "Fish" related professions in the Census of 1901 and 1911

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Strict specifications governed their size, shape and construction. Only dry, heavy wood could be used to make them and faulty barrels were destroyed. Barrels which failed to make the requirements not only let pickle leak out but also let air leak in therefore contaminating the fish and spoiling the cure. The other component of the curing workforce were those who gutted and packed the herring, this was a predominately female occupation. Plate 1.1 captures this division of labour. This labour was not local but comprised of Scottish and Donegal girls and in the curing harbours of Ardglass and Kilkeel this was evident. (Pollock,per.com.) The women did not hire individually but organised themselves into groups of three to join up as a crew of two gutters and a packer. (Mrs. E.Moore, oral evidence.) The system of payment employed by the curing industry imbursed the crew as a whole according to the number of barrels it filled more at www.angelfire.com/mn/marion/herring.html
